Alternate payers

when he was between jobs.

A payroll deduct example (1 of 3) G

¢ Alarge employer pays premiums on employees’ personal line insurance policies
¢ Insurer offers discounted premium if employees pay through their paychecks
¢ Employer automatically deducts premium payments from employee paychecks
¢ The employees benefit:
a Discounted insurance
if Convenience of no extra bills to pay
¢ The insurer benefits:
a More predictable cash flow
wt Typically, premium is paid early
av Reduced operational costs
av Reduced likelihood of returned checks

The employer pays all the charges for several policyholders

the Multiple Payment Entry
wizard to record payments.

Recording list bill/overriding payer payments Gi

* Billing clerk uses the Multiple Payment Entry wizard to record payments

« Recommended: Split large payment into smaller payments and allocate payments at the
account, policy, or invoice level

Overview Account Basics

Alternate payer considerations

Marci
Configuration
Developer

8

Now that you know more about list bill

<~ payers, let’s discuss the factors to

consider when deciding which type of
alternate payer to use.

Determining which type of alternate payer to use

Assuming a single account pays for multiple policies it does not own

nl

* Generally, Guidewire recommends using list bill accounts because list bill
accounts have performance enhancements that overriding payers do not

* However: A list bill account cannot own policies whereas an overriding payer account can
¢ A policy that requires multiple payers must make use of overriding payers
¢ For fewer than 50 policies:
* Set billing method to List Bill on the policies and use a list bill account payer, OR
* Set billing method to Direct Bill on the policies and use an overriding payer
¢ For 50 to 1,000 policies:
* Set billing method to List Bill on the policies and use a list bill account payer
¢ For over 1,000 policies, distribute the work (as described on the next slide)

Performance considerations for alternate payers G

¢ Apayer with a large number of policies adversely impacts performance

* Batch processes such as Invoice, Invoice Due, and New Payment can fail to complete work
within the nightly window

¢ Screens such as Invoices and Charges take more time to render
« Payment reconciliation is more difficult when a mistake occurs
* Guidewire recommends:
¢ Distribute work over multiple payer accounts
+ Distribute work over time
+ Example: Invoice some monthly policies on the 1st of the month, others on the 2"4, and so on

+ Process payments as batch payments

Consult your Guidewire Customer Support representative about sizing list bill accounts
